title: Environmental Problems in Hong Kong
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for Biology, Environmental Science and Geography and Resource Management Majors.
description: The purposes of this course are to: (1) introduce students to the environmental problems encountered in Hong Kong; (2) help students to understand the scientific nature of these environmental problems; (3) enable students to use scientific concepts developed in the course to evaluate the options available in dealing with these environmental problems; and (4) provide students with a general overview of the Hong Kong Government's environmental programmes. (This course is suitable for first year students.)
outcome: 1. Recognize the major environmental problems in Hong Kong. 2. Understand the scientific basis of air, noise and water pollution. 3. Understand the problem of waste disposal and waste management in Hong Kong. 4. Understand the role played by Hong Kong people in the global biodiversity crisis. 5. Apply scientific knowledge to: i) examine all aspects of environmental issues, ii) make scientific judgments about environmental issues, and iii) critically evaluate the Hong Kong Government’s environmental programmes, strategies and policies. 6. Apply scientific and ecological knowledge to live in an environmentally friendly and sustainable manner.
syllabus: Major concepts include:  1) Sustainable development 2) Urban planning policy 3) Air pollution 4) Noise pollution 5) Solid waste management 6) Water pollution 7) Conservation of biodiversity 8) Environmental ethics and economics

title: Science and Our Lives
requirements: For Shaw College students. Not for students of Faculty of Engineering, Faculty of Medicine and Faculty of Science.
description: This General Education course is jointly offered by the Biology Department and Shaw College. This course introduces students to biological issues closely related to our daily life. More specifically, issues with different levels of complexity, ranging from cellular to ecosystem dynamics that form the intimate and integrated part of our very own existence will be discussed. Topics related to medical, genetic, physiological, ecological and environmental issues will be covered. Specific contents of the course may change according to timely issues. Students will gain a general appreciation of how our lives are closely linked with changes and developments in the biological systems around us.
outcome: 1. To obtain a basic understanding of how the biological system works around us.  2. To understand how changes and developments in the biological system are closely linked to our daily life.  3. To appreciate latest developments in research on our biological system.   4. With the knowledge gained, to become more responsive citizens to issues related to changes and developments in the biological system around us.
syllabus: Major topics to be covered include, but not limited to the followings:  1. Emergence of life and evolution 2. Cellular mechanisms and processes 3. Animal and plant behaviour 4. Physiological dynamics and adaptations 5. Population and community interactions 6. Ecosystem functions and services 7. Biological application and technology  Specific topics will be taken up depending on timely issues, to make the course more relevant to our daily life.

title: He Said, She Said: Gender and Language
requirements: For Shaw College students only.
description: This course is an introduction to the study of how women and men communicate. Students need not have any previous linguistic training to enroll in the course. Students will consider some of the debates currently taking place in sociolinguistic studies of gender (e.g., which theoretical frameworks to use in understanding why, how and when gender differences in language use exist). Though this debate takes a particular form within sociolinguistics (e.g., dual culture models vs. power/resistance models), similar debates take place in psychology, history, anthropology, and other fields. The course introduces students to a variety of sociolinguistic concepts as they are used and useful in studies of language and gender (including style, dialect, standard and nonstandard language, speech community, bilingualism, politeness, and communicative competence). This course is suitable for first year students.

title: Film Genres: Love, Death and Laughs
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Journalism and Communication Majors cannot take this course to fulfill General Education requirements.
description: (GESC2010 is double-coded with COMM2932.) This course focuses on a variety of film genres, such as detective and gangster film, musicals, comedies, family dramas and westerns. Genres have been popular since the beginning of the film medium and remain quite popular today. This class will examine the cultural and economic reasons for their continuing popularity. Film showings and film clips will demonstrate how genres evolve over time and how some of the great film directors have made genre films of lasting impact. This class assumes no prior knowledge of film. Students will be assessed on the basis of a paper and an examination.
outcome: Be the end of the course, students should: 1. Be knowledgeable about different film genres. 2. Be knowledgeable about the history and development of film genres. 3. Be able to examine how film forms are related to content as well as to culture.

title: History of Food: Hong Kong Food Culture
requirements: For Shaw College students only.
description: Food and drinks are crucial to the survival of humans. The production of food, its distribution, preparation and presentation are clothed in meanings and surrounded by rituals. Changes in food culture reflect changes in the context of the wider culture. This course examines the origins and social evolution of food. Through discussions on the functions, structures, social and political roles, and the medicinal use of food, we seek to understand the emergence and evolution characteristics of our own society. Field trips will be organized to explore the evolution of Hong Kong society through food experiences.

title: Debating Globalization
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for students who have taken UGEC2514 or SOCI4203.
description: Through a combination of experiential learning activities and web-based delivery, this course aims at expose students to a number of intense debates surrounding globalization such as free trade, global culture, national sovereignty, the question of multinational corporations and labour rights and the anti-globalization movement. The objective is to build basic knowledge of the opposing views on globalization, their political and ideological bases, and implications for political and personal actions. More importantly, through the experiential learning activities built in the course, we aim at helping students develop the sensitivity and competences necessary to interpret our everyday life experiences in the light of globalization and to articulate their personal positions on a host of life and career issues. Students could check out our course homepage for more information via: http://debating-globalization.net/.
outcome: (1) To recognize the key concepts, theories and issues surrounding the debates of globalization. (2) To interpret and discuss the relevance to and impacts of globalization on everyday life experiences. (3) To demonstrate personal learning experience through activities in the context of globalization in daily life. (4) To demonstrate the mastery of skills in information collection, retrieval and analysis, as well as the use of such information in the analysis of concrete situations of everyday life experience. (5) To articulate and defend an individual position on key debates issues arising from globalization and engage in a dialogue with and appreciation of College visions and missions pertaining to the relationship between individual students and community concerns

title: The World of Football: A Social Science Perspective
requirements: For Shaw College students only.
description: This course is intended to introduce students to theories and concepts in various disciplines of social sciences for analysing probably the most popular sport game in the world, namely football. Students are expected to critically examine the development of football into a global game from historical, sociological, political, economic, cultural as well as gender perspectives. Particular emphasis is placed on the rise of football and modernity, the commercialization of football and global restructuring, and football culture in the light of nationalism, racism, class and gender. The objective is to cultivate critical thinking among the students, giving them an opportunity to analyse a popular sport and to reflect upon the relevance of social science knowledge to their understanding of global phenomenon in their everyday life.

title: Critical Thinking of Human Nature and Civilization Through Movies
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for students who have taken JASP1130, 1140, 1150, UGEC1293 or 1302.
description: The objective of this course is to understand human nature, including our desire, fear and virtue, through interdisciplinary reading and discussion of movies from different parts of the world. Students will discuss in groups and present their opinions/findings in class based on the class work they have done and make references from their daily life experiences and the situation in Hong Kong.
outcome: GESC2080_outcomes     Through this course, students will have acquired the ability to examine movies from different parts of the world including Japan, America and Europe; and knowledge about the history, society and culture of the corresponding places. This allows them to compare and contrast the relationship between human nature and civilizations of different eras and races, and to reflect on the possible connections between such findings and their own experiences and the development of Hong Kong. Students will have improved their critical thinking, presentation skills and research abilities through class work, group discussions, presentations and essay writing.

title: Exploring Major Themes in Literature
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for English Majors.
description: This course will offer a broad survey of classic and modem literature. Through close reading and class discussions, students will explore major themes occurring in various literary genres (i.e., poetry, short stories, and plays). This course is designed to improve students' ability to comprehend and enjoy literary works in English. The course will provide guidance and practice in critical reading and will involve class discussion, group work, writing and basic research, including the use of the library and the internet.

title: Rethinking Modern Technology
requirements: For Shaw College students only.
description: This course reflects on the impact of modern technology on everyday life. It gives an introduction to the philosophy of technology and the relations of technology to environment, society and culture. Focus will be given to the ethical issues arising from the rapid developments of information, computer and biomedical technology. Major discussion topics include intellectual property, privacy, information control, virtual reality, artificial intelligence, human cloning, genetic engineering and stem cell research. The course aims to stimulate students to think critically about the technology that is changing the world in a fundamental way.

title: Questions of a Modern Person
requirements: For Shaw College Students only.
description: By introducing students to the socio-economic, political and cultural foundation of complex and pluralistic modern societies, this course will help first year university students reflect on the key issues they will encounter in their transition to adulthood and adjustment to this new phase of their personal development. This course attempts to provide students with a wider interdisciplinary perspective, to introduce them to different relevant factors and various ways of approach to the problems of modern person. We hope to enhance their self-awareness of the need of recognizing differences and being tolerant, as well as the diversity of moral values and beliefs in modern society. There will be lectures, discussions, debates, multi-media presentations, interviews, on-site visits wherever and whenever appropriate and available.
outcome: Questions of a Modern Person - learning outcomes       1.      To recognize key concepts, theories and issues regarding the formation of modernity and the mentality of modern person. 2.      To identify the major social forces that shape students’ transition to adulthood and their impacts on their adjustment to university life. 3.      To recognize the diversity of values and beliefs in modern societies as well as the origins of such diversity. 4.      To apply the theoretical knowledge in the reflection of their role as university student in society and to relate this reflection to their status of future community leaders. 5.      To demonstrate through project and other learning activities the skills in information gathering and processing, as well as the ability to cooperate with other people in team work.

title: Gender Issues in Hong Kong
description: (GESC2115 is double-coded with GDRS1301.) (Students who have taken GDRS1301 cannot take this course to fulfil General Education requirements.) This course aims at sensitising students to the various manifestations and implications of gender issues in Hong Kong. It starts off by introducing concepts and perspectives which might be useful in understanding gender divisions and inequalities. It then proceeds to review gender relations in different spheres of local life. These include: the family, employment, education, politics and the law. This course ends with a brief discussion of the past, present and future state of women's movement in Hong Kong.

title: Challenges of University Life
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Students who have taken UGED1600 or SOWK1150 cannot take this course to fulfil General Education requirements.
description: (Students who have taken UGED1600 or SOWK1150 cannot take this course to fulfil General Education requirements.) This course aims at helping students discover and rediscover some of the issues surrounding the individual as a young adult actively participating in a university life. The main theme has to do with effective blending of individual behaviour into the social environment. Topics include: human behaviour from a behavioural and a cognitive point of view, nature of education and social control, power of language in shaping how people perceive and think about social issues, bonding between people, learning at a tertiary level, and career development. It is hoped that through guided discussions on these general issues, students could develop their own thinking about them, and strategies to address them.

title: Comprehending the City
requirements: For Shaw College Students only. Not for Geography and Resource Management Majors.
description: City living is a modern way of life and sustainability has become the central issue of urban development. By 2020, it is expected that about 60% of the worlds’s population will live in cities. Cities are thus the places where touch most the quality of life. With the development of economy, society and technology, cities have undergone dramatic changes in their strength, structure and direction. Some cities continue to prosper while others experience declining. How individuals and urban communities can survive and even prosper demands a good understanding of the urban systems. This course will be devoted to the investigation of the growth dynamics of cities, their economic, social and environmental problems and the ways to develop sustainable cities. Many daily life examples of Hong Kong and other cities in China and western countries will be used to illustrate various urban contradictions and problems. After being equipped with the knowledge of various urban issues and problems, students are expected to contribute their knowledge to the urban communities by participating well planned service learning projects in this course and then further enhance their ability to learn effectively through service. After taking this course, students will be well-prepared for challenges in world cities such as Hong Kong and equipped with the knowledge and the vision to become a responsible and concerned urban resident with a passion of caring for people and communities.

After taking this course, students will have: 1.         Demonstrated a general and multi-faceted understanding of the diversity and complexity of modern cities; 2.         Assessed the contradictive natures of the cities; 3.         Criticizied the various urban problems in Hong Kong; and 4.         Developed the ability to contribute urban knowledge to the communities. Along with the knowledge enhancement on cities, students will be able to further improve their critical thinking and analytical capability through problem-based teaching and service learning approach.

title: Media, Culture and Society
requirements: For Shaw College students only
description: This course explores how mass media - music, video, prints, television, Internet, etc. - affects cultures and societies. Based mainly on, but not limited to, anthropological perspective, this course will discuss how mass media is not just part of our culture and cultural products; but a very important part and an everyday context for the making of culture. This course will examine the processes of mass media production, circulation and consumption to address the following issues: 1) how mass media affect the representation and reproduction of different cultures and societies, 2) how mass media representations contribute to national and transnational identities, 3) how both governmental and market forces create and restrict possibilities of mass media representations, and 4) how technological development affects the relationships among mass media, culture and society. Through investigating the relationship between mass media, society and culture, this course aims at not only acquiring basic idea about anthropology and mass media studies but, more importantly, on reflective and critical thinking regarding who we are and cultural differences in the society we live. To encourage learning through experience - in the field -, not just classroom interactions, this course will include two fieldtrips. One of the trips will focus on the production of mass media. The class will visit and interview mass media producers - music studios, editors of popular magazines, website managers, etc. - at there work sites to learn about the concerns and conditions of mass media production. The other one will focus on the distribution and consumption of mass media. The class will visit a public space where vigorous commercial activities constantly taking place - for example, the Times Square Open Piazza, to observe and investigate what sorts of mass media are presented, how they, together with people, buildings, etc., made of the space, and also how various people passed by engage in different form of mass mediation.

People (and their speeches) in modern history have been chosen, for their contributions to human right, to peace and love, and to wellness of mankind. title: Canvassing Cantonese
requirements: For Shaw College Student only. Not for Chinese Language and Literature, and Linguistics Majors.
description: In this course, we will study the following issues of Cantonese: the relation between the sounds of Cantonese lyrics and the melody of the accompanying music; the diversity of word formation and the architecture of sentence patterns in Cantonese trendy expressions; the language in Stephen Chow’s movies as representative of the historical development of Cantonese; the cultural meanings encoded in Cantonese slang; the difficulties that new immigrants /students from the Mainland encounter in learning Cantonese; the impact that the study of Cantonese has on general linguistic theory; the resemblance between Cantonese, or even Mandarin, grammar and mathematics. These issues are within the four general areas of language studies, namely, general linguistics, socio-historical linguistics, educational linguistics and interface inquiry. This course will provide participants with service-learning activities, such as analyzing the difficulty that new immigrants/ students from the Mainland have in distinguishing Cantonese tones, discussing with teachers how the use of trendy expressions in Hong Kong affects secondary students’ writing performance in Chinese, and documenting the changes in Cantonese by comparing Cantonese movies collected in Hong Kong Film Archive with present-day movies. It is hoped that the activities will allow students to combine theoretical and practical knowledge together and to further enhance their appreciation of the complexity of Cantonese grammar.

title: Poverty Alleviation and Development in China: Service Learning Project
requirements: For Shaw College students only.
description: Since 1978, China’s population under absolute poverty has decreased from 250 million to 15 million. China has successful poverty eradication and development experience, but still many Chinese people are living in poverty and the gap between the rich and the poor are widening. Summarization and reflection of the experience of poverty eradication in China, is significant to poor people in China and the world. This General Education Course is offered by Shaw College, which adopts Service-Learning method, requires students to conduct field visit, research and service in poor area of China. Students can understand the needs of the residents by participating in the interviews with community residents. Being engaged in direct service, students can understand values and difficulties of the projects. Finally, students are required to evaluate different poverty alleviation strategies of Government and NGOs in their reporting sessions. This course is multi-disciplinary studies which call for a collaborative effort between students with interests in poverty and development.

title: The Road to Social Entrepreneurship
requirements: For Shaw College students only.
description: A social entrepreneur seeks out innovative ways to address community needs. This course provides fundamental social entrepreneurship training and community involvement experience to Shaw College students by incorporating a service-learning framework into the course design. Students will gain insight of social entrepreneurism via attending a series of lectures and workshops at the beginning of the course. An overview of the global and local development of social enterprises will be provided at the beginning, followed by intensive social entrepreneurship skills training. Field trips to social enterprises with diverse background will be organised. Groups of students will then collaborate with these social enterprises and together decide an innovative and mutually beneficial way of service. This negotiated service will be continuously assessed by the supervisors from these social enterprises as well as the course coordinator. Upon finishing designated hours of service students are required to reflect on their learning experience, draft and submit a group report, and present their report in class in the final lecture.

title: From Page to Stage-Exploring the Art of Drama and Theatre
requirements: For Shaw College Students only.
description: Through lecture and seminar, students will be introduced to the following famous plays in the world: A Doll’s House, Death of a Salesman, Waiting For Godot, Thunder Storm, and The Silly Girl and the Funny Old Tree. The latter part of the course will be dedicated to practical work including rehearsals and technical theatre operations in attempts to stage excerpts from these plays. Students will be divided into groups of 5. As such, the plays covered in the course will be introducing to the students a good spectrum of world dramatic history and literature. The Shaw College Lecture Theatre will be used as the teaching, rehearsing and performing venue.Offerings with different topics can be taken for credit up to a maximum of two times.
outcome: 1. Students will acquire basic understanding of world drama throughout the ages including play analysis and critique. 2. Students will discover the differentiation between serious art, which is directly related to living and humanity, and entertainment. 3. Students will operate in a complete cycle of theatre production. 4. What would result is that personal speech and communication skills will be enhanced. 5. Students will learn to employ what they have learned in an environment of teamwork and cooperation in the theatrical production in their later lives. 6. Students will be able to identify and judge the results of the knowledge of the arts in general. 7. Personal abilities such as self-esteem and attributes such as latent talents will be enhanced. 8. Some students will demonstrate their potentials as leaders as the course is also about leadership training.
syllabus: 1. The forms of drama, viz. tragedy, comedy, tragi-comedy, farce and melodrama. 2. The six elements of drama according to Aristotle. 3. The linear structure in conventional drama. 4. Styles of theatre from Classicism to Post-modernism. 5. The dramaturgy of the 5 plays mentioned above. 6. The theatre production procedures – from rehearsal to opening. 7. Lighting, scenorgraphy and sound design 8. Stage management 9. The working schedules 10. The work of a theatre producer – marketing, publicity, ticketing and customer service.

title: Appreciation of Life
requirements: For Shaw College Students only.
description: This course aims at introducing students to appreciate different art forms that include but not limited to traditional and contemporary paintings by masters in the East and the West, classical and popular music as well as operas, porcelain, jade and other important antiques of China to be completed with a virtual tour in China and around the world in order to understand their historical linkage and cultural heritage. The course shall broaden students’ perspective and repertoire in the appreciation and understanding of different art forms. The ultimate goal is to help students better appreciate and enjoy the diverse aspects of life that we may overlook in our everyday life.

title: Corporate Social Responsibility: A Global Perspective
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for students of Faculty of Business Administration.
description: This course presents corporate social responsibility from a global perspective. In addition to learning the academic background of corporate social responsibility in classroom settings through lectures, discussions and presentations, students also take part in an experiential study outside Hong Kong to understand and experience corporate cultures that promote social responsibility from a global perspective.

title: Social Entrepreneurship - Innovating Social Change
requirements: For Shaw College Students only.
description: Social enterprise aims to achieve the triple bottom lines of community needs, environmental concern and business profitability. Social enterprises generate revenue to support their ultimate social missions. Although they run in a business basis, they put the profit back to serve the community and disadvantaged groups. In this course students will be introduced the development and practical operations of social enterprises locally in Hong Kong and globally around the world. Students will learn the essence of social enterprises in addressing social needs as business opportunities. Through sharing by social entrepreneurs and site visits, students will gain an insider look on the success factors of social enterprises, how government policies affect social enterprises, and challenges and concerns of social enterprises in Hong Kong. Through hands-on projects students will also learn to develop sensitivity to social issues and business acumen. This course serves as a foundation course to enroll in the GESC2230 The Road to Social Entrepreneurship that focuses on service-learning.

title: Develop your Strengths toward New Economy
requirements: For Shaw College Students only.
description: This course adopts an experiential approach to explore ways the new generation needs to equip themselves in response to the changes in social structure and the breakout of Financial Tsunami. It will also illustrate the soft skills and appropriate work manner that is unavailable in traditional classroom while being useful for audience to develop their personal sustainability. With the growing importance of China, this course will illustrate the way to learn and explore the opportunity of this economic giant through first hand experience and practical exercises.

title: Follow the Footprints: Explore Different Poles
requirements: For Shaw College Students only.
description: This course explores both the geographical and cultural aspects of extreme environments across the world including the coldest extremes like the Arctic and Antarctica, the hottest extreme like Taklamakan Desert, the highest extreme like Mount Everest, and the lowest extreme like Yarlung Zangbo Grand Canyon. Students will learn about the scientific expeditions of these regions and also their cultural heritages. This is an exciting journey to appreciate how people, environment, culture and arts are tightly integrated from these disparate places in the world.

title: The Psychology of Civic Contribution
requirements: For Shaw College students only.
description: This is an action-learning course that students will learn theories and findings of prosocial behaviours that they will apply their knowledge to devise campaigns that encourage the public to contribute to the society like protecting the environment, engaging in volunteer work, donating to charitable organizations, conserving energy, etc. With the understanding of the facilitating and inhibiting factors of prosocial behaviours, students are agents of change to promote a civil society.

title: Gender and Family: a Global Perspective
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for students who have taken SOCI3208 or SOCI2218[3222]. However, student who have taken GESC2320 can take SOCI3208 and SOCI2218[3222].
description: Gender is a pivotal aspect of family relationships. The family is a domain where unequal gender relationships between men and women are systematically created and reproduced. As a social institution, the family, through its distribution of resources, division of labour, and perceptions about gender identity, reinforces a hierarchical relationship between men and women in which men are privileged. On the one hand, the family is an important interactive arena for examining how people produce and do gender, and how gender strategies are created in everyday life. On the other hand, gender is a tool for dissecting the structure of family, its processes, and the outcomes of interactions between its members. This course aims to investigate the complex links between gender and family from a global perspective. It highlights cultural and national similarities and differences in gender and family relationships, the diversities in state responses to the emerging challenges on gender and family relationships globally, and the rapid development of a globalized discourse of gender equality that is based on calls for universal human rights, on blurring the public and private divide and on challenging the boundaries between family and society.
outcome: Students in this course should study and demonstrate understanding of the interconnection between gender and family in shaping individual life chances, the distribution of resources and power, and the division of roles between the two sexes.  Students are also expected to develop a global view on differences and similarities between gender and family across cultures and societies, as well as the diversities in state responses to the emerging challenges on gender and family relationships globally. More generally, students should acquire a set of analytical skills and methods to critically reflect on the concept of gender in contributing to our understanding of societies and cultures; to understand the diversified family formation process, family patterns and practices, the role of evidence and research methods in cross cultural comparative analysis; the role of transferable skills and insights beyond national and cultural boundaries, and the development of global values of human rights and equality for reflecting on the social reality of own society and individual biography, as well as one’s value positions and life choices.
syllabus: The major concepts to be covered include: The conceptual distinctions between sex and gender; the multicultural understanding of family, and the concept of globalization. The major topics to be covered include: 1) the conceptual interconnection between gender and family; 2) cultural and national diversities in understanding of family, its structure and dynamics; 3) the intersection between the public and the private domain as evidenced by close links between unpaid housework and paid employment, the more intricate interrelations between paid household work provided by foreign domestic helper and the family, the tension between parenting and work, and ;4) the globalized movement towards gender equality as illustrated by global networks and advocacy against domestic violence and sexual harassment, and the global call for family policies that promote gender equality and gender mainstreaming.

title: Service Learning: Genuine Care and Human Concern for the Society
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for Social Work Major.
description: This is a service learning course which integrates meaningful social service activity with instruction and critical reflection in class to enrich the learning and the betterment of society, aims to foster students with genuine care and human concern for the needs and problems of society. Based on the principles of service- learning, altruism, volunteerism and reflective learning, students are required to apply theories and concepts to design and implement a series of service for a chosen community issue or a special target group affiliated with a non-governmental organization. On the way of the service, on-site supervision, reflection, discussion and presentation sessions are arranged to help students have an in-depth reflection and understanding to the needs of vulnerable groups and the relationship between individuals and the society. Ultimately, it is expected that students are able to develop a long-term civil commitment to the well-being and betterment of society.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. Appraise in depth their personal, social, emotional, cognitive and intellectual development in relation to their service- learning experience; 2. Apply the theories and skills they learnt to assess critically on the needs and situations of a vulnerable group, in turn, to plan and identify a series of action for the situations;  3. Appreciate the practices and values of service-learning, altruism, volunteerism and civil engagement in bringing about a care and concern society;  4. Have genuine care and human concern for the vulnerable situations in society;  5. Develop a long-term civil commitment to the well-being and betterment of society;  6. Practice constant self-reflection in order to achieve self-discovery and self-advancement.

title: Scripting Life
requirements: For Shaw College Students only.
description: This course trains students to appreciate critically dimensions of culture and power from both local and global perspectives through writing a short play. The course will be conducted in three stages. In the first stage students will be taught to appreciate master pieces and to appraise critically the underlying political, philosophical and power themes of the play. During the process students also learn basic writing skills. Students are required to choose a topic that inspires them the most. Through field visits, they will observe how people communicate with each other under different social contexts. Students will note down the register variations in dialogues as reference materials for writing. In the second stage students will engage in intensive writing with close guidance of the instructor to ensure that their chosen theme can adequately be depicted through the play. In the third stage students will read and comment on each other’s work in order to polish the play. Throughout the three stages of appreciating masterpieces, researching and writing one’s play and commenting on each other’s work, students engage in an active and critical exploration of the impact of culture, politics and power on one’s own life.

title: Society and Disability
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for Social Work Major and students who have taken SOWK4540.
description: This course helps students understand the psychosocio-political aspects of disability. Theoretical models ranging from medical to social model, and practice models ranging from the therapeutic approach to the independent living approach will be examined. The course will also address the social construction of disability, and include discussion on sociological-psychological concepts and critical issues relevant to service designs in present-day social context, with a view to create an enabling environment for persons with disabilities.
outcome: Students will have: - Familiarized themselves with disability-related psychological and sociological concepts and theories in contemporary society - Made critical appraisal of the extent to which current social and political policies developed to meet the needs of people with disabilities in society.
syllabus: This course is divided into the following parts. Part 1 deals with the historical and cultural perspectives of treating people with disability. Part 2 focuses on the theoretical and practical frameworks of disability. Part 3 handles the selected types of disability. Part 4 concentrates on professional workers’ roles in serving their clients with special needs. The course is designed to cover the following topics:  - A brief history of the ways different cultures have treated persons with a disability; - Societal and professional stereotypes towards disability; - Different theoretical models such as the medical model, the social model, the empowerment model, etc.; - Selected disabilities such as the developmental disabilities; mental disorders; visual impairment; hearing impairment; persons with psychiatric disability; etc. - Social services for persons with a disability, and - The roles of professional workers in working with clients who have a disability and their families.

title: Environmental Justice in Action
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for students who have taken SOCI3212.
description: Environmental justice is a social movement originated from the United States. This movement helps developing conceptual tools and strategies to discuss and eliminate unfair, unjust, and inequitable conditions and decisions in issues regarding environmental destruction. Through the lens of environmental justice, this course explores the intricate relationship between social inequalities and the environment. It begins with conceptual discussion of environmental justice and then move to evaluate mitigating actions of both business sectors and civil society to environmental injustice. This course also adopts an ‘action research’ approach in order to encourage students to apply their knowledge to address environmental issues of inequality and unjust in their communities and daily life.

title: Cultural Tourism Kaleidoscope
requirements: For Shaw College students only.
description: Hong Kong is often regarded as a kaleidoscope of cultural fusion of East and West with a traditional Chinese heritage, a distinctive British colonial history and a vision for cosmopolitanism. This course is designed to provide students with a sociological approach to understand the society we live in, through critical examination of local tourism products including festivals and events, theme parks, heritage trails, urban regeneration and ecotourism. Students are expected to carry ethnographic fieldworks and analyze the society through personal experience and independent researches.

title: Genetic Engineering and Its Impacts on Our Society
requirements: For Shaw College students only. Not for Faculty of Medicine and School of Life Sciences major students.
description: This course intends to introduce basic concepts of gene functions, genetic engineering, synthetic biology and the impacts of gene technology on our society. Since the genetic sequences of human beings and many different organisms become available, their role in biological processes and diseases become more understood and comprehensible to human beings. Possibilities of making good use of such bioinformatics knowledge and manipulation of genes have opened a brave new world for us. Genetic engineering of biological organisms aims to help human beings resolve problems associated with our sustainability on planet earth in various aspects of health and medical cares, food and energy supply, environmental sustainability, industrial production and monitoring, etc, all of which have significant impacts on our society as a whole, despite some might cause much debate.
outcome: After completing this course, the students are expected to: [1] understand the meaning of the terms and concepts of gene technology, human genome and genome projects, genetic engineering, synthetic biology, eugenics, bioethics; [2] understand the diversity of genes in populations, recombinant DNA methods, concepts of genetic screening and gene therapy; [3] understand the concepts of how genes affect our behaviours; [4] understand what genetically modified foods are and their contributions; [5] understand the uses and misuses of animal cloning; [6] understand the potential uses of synthetic biology for making drugs and biofuels [7] learn from specific cases which receive much attention of the ethical use of technologies in sports, reproduction and medicare research; [8] understand the considerations and laws regulating fertilization, reproduction, and biosafety.
syllabus: [1] Basic concepts of human reproduction and genetics [2] Our genome, genetic diversity, genetic diseases, genetic diagnosis [3] DNA manipulation, recombinant DNA, DNA synthesis, and artificial life [4] Genetically modified organisms and genetically modified foods: myths and facts [5] Gene screening, gene therapy, and personalised DNA sequencing for better medicare [6] Animal cloning, stem cells and their potential applications [7] Do we have our rights to select our off-springs to be born? [8] Learn how to design an organism you want: the iGEM way [9] Current practises and laws in Hong Kong and around the world about biosafety and reproduction [10-12] Case studies: group project presentations

title: Concise Financial Literacy
requirements: 1. For Shaw College students only;2. Not for IFAA, QFIN, QFRM and GLEF majors;3. Not for students who have taken UGEC1560, ECON1420, ECON3410, ECON3420 or ECON3520
description: Everything we see around in the world today is more or less a product of financing and investments activities. The home we live in, the car or train we ride on, or the food we eat, all these pass through various economic cycles to reach us in their present form. Yet in the aftermath of financial crises there is a big misunderstanding among the masses as to what finance and investments is. There are so many cases about fallen integrity involving financial institutions and finance practitioners that generally people have started associating finance and investments with tricks and fraudulent practices. Understanding finance and investment thus becomes essential so we can go beyond such narrow narratives and understand finance better to live our lives productively and fully, irrespective of what job we chose for ourselves as we grow.This course enlightens students about investments, various institutions of modern financial world, important financial instruments and ethical standards expected of us while operating in this world and about money itself and this trains them up whether they chose a salaried job or become an entrepreneur. Young students who are curious about the “magic” and mechanics of the financial world (of which Hong Kong is one of the key centres), or if they are mystified about the inner workings of certain difficult and arcane financial transactions, this course will demystify this whole “alchemy” of financial world. The course is simple for students from any stream to follow, based on dozens of real life stories told by an industry expert and a story teller.
outcome: After this course the students are expected to: 1. Appreciate what is finance and investments in reality. They will understand various pillars of financial world and how the economies work and how one financial institution is linked to the other. 2. Know what money is and what are banks, investment banks, various funds such as hedge funds, private equity funds, venture capital funds and how these institutions work. They will know what and how insurance firm works, the role of audit and law firms in economies and role of number of minor players such as agents, custodians and various agencies.  3. Understand various methods of raising capital, debts, equities, bonds, mortgages, and learn about the institutions that are providing capital. 4. Be no longer incomprehensible to bonds, options, contracts, swaps and alternative assets. 5. Better understand the importance of care in investment and financial analysis. The course will have introduced methodologies and importance of due care and prepares them for trying out entrepreneurship and portfolio management. 6. Learn the virtues of high ethical and moral standards in financial services industry. They will learn to identify conflict of interest situations and get to learn importance of strong character and high ethical values to be successful in financial world.

This course is designed to provide students with the most updated scientific knowledge about what emotions are, how emotion dysregulation results in different emotional disorders (e.g. anxiety disorders and mood disorders), and what one can do to overcome emotional disturbances and transform emotions into positive forces which serve adaptive purposes. title: Leadership in Uncertain Era
requirements: For students of Shaw College.
description: Learning leadership is essential as leading one’s own life is also a kind of leadership. This course aims to promote a new idea of service leadership by cultivating appropriate knowledge, skills, character and care towards self, others, and the society. It is particularly important to understand this body of knowledge when the sense of security is in vain due to constant restructuring of organizations in response to globalization and neo-liberalism. The course will introduce students to theories of leadership from the disciplines of sociology, political science, psychology and management. Leadership in business, politics, non-profits and social innovation will be discussed. Distinguished leaders in these fields will be invited to share their experiences.

title: Exploring Night Sky
requirements: 1. For Shaw College students only.;2. Not for students who have taken UGEB2510.
description: Since ancient time, human beings have been curious about and fascinating with the remote sky. This curiosity and fascination have boosted the invention of various techniques in observational astronomy and, on the other hand, the spread of mythology about constellations under cultural influences. This course introduces the mythology in both the East and the West, stimulating students to ponder on the cultural significances behind the stories. In addition, students are encouraged to practice basic techniques in observational astronomy, acquiring knowledge through experiential learning. No scientific knowledge beyond junior secondary education is assumed.
outcome: Students are expected to (i) gain basic knowledge and techniques in observational astronomy, (ii) to acquire an ability to apply observational astronomy to organize stargazing activities, and (iii) to have an acquaintance with mythology about constellations in both the East and the West.
syllabus: Major topics include: • Celestial Sphere: Introduction to basic concept of celestial sphere such as the apparent motions of celestial objects.  • Stars and Constellations: Naked-eye observations of various celestial objects such as planets, the Moon, and binary stars; constellations in different seasons. • Stargazer Aids: Introduction to the principles of binoculars and telescopes; choices and uses of the observation aids. • Astronomical Imaging: Introduction to astrophotography • Greco-Roman Mythology: Brief historical background of Ancient Greek and Roman mythology • Chinese Mythology: Chinese constellations and the historical stories in China.

title: Learning Management through humanities
requirements: For Shaw College students only.
description: This course attempts to learn management through the study of humanities, including mythology, fables, philosophy, literature, idioms, history, songs, movies, cartoons and speeches. This course also provides a broad intellectual perspective and understanding for the study of management through various aspects and approaches from humanities; helps students reflect on studies with daily life, prompting them to make connections between intellectual pursuits and daily life; and develop an understanding of Chinese and western culture, mythology, philosophy, idioms and history.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. Arouse the interests in management through humanities;2. Comprehend management through humanities, especially mythology, philosophy, literature, history, music and various aspects in humanities;3. Understand different aspects and themes in management through humanities
